{{Infobox person | name = Maximilian Conze | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|1969|11|04}} --> | birth_place = [[Bielefeld]], Germany | nationality = German | alma_mater = [[Columbus State University]] | occupation = Businessman | years_active = 1993-present | title = Unemployed | term = 2011-09/10/2017 | predecessor = Martin McCourt | successor = Incumbent | spouse = Bettina | children = Two }}
'''Maximilian Conze'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.flixens.com/director/maximilian-walter-conze|title=MAXIMILIAN WALTER CONZE - Company Director Check|website=www.flixens.com|access-date=2017-09-13}}</ref> (born 1969) was appointed Chief Executive of [[Dyson (company)|Dyson]] in 2011. His vision for geographic expansion in Asia and growth of the company's product portfolio has had high impact and in 2016 Dyson recorded a turnover of £2.51bn (up 45% on prior year)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.southwestbusiness.co.uk/sectors/manufacturing/dyson-reports-45-per-cent-profit-growth-to--2-5bn-28032017091528/|title=Dyson reports 45 per cent profit growth to £2.5bn {{!}} Blog|website=www.southwestbusiness.co.uk|access-date=2017-09-13}}</ref>. Under Conze’s leadership the company is investing 2.5 billion into future technologies<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-wiltshire-39117982|title=Dyson to open second tech campus|date=2017-03-01|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-09-13|language=en-GB}}</ref>. Dyson has 40 new products in development, is launching the Dyson Institute of Engineering and Technology - a new university based in Malmesbury and has an ambition for new battery technology. Conze’s strong belief is “Our lifeblood is inventing and to do this we must aggressively bring in bright young engineering talent."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/industry/9075642/Interview-Dyson-CEO-Max-Conze-Our-lifeblood-is-inventing.-That-is-where-we-spend-all-of-our-money..html|title=Interview Dyson CEO Max Conze: 'Our lifeblood is inventing. That is where we spend all of our money.'|last=Ahmed|first=Kamal|date=2012-02-11|access-date=2017-09-13|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
==Early life== Conze was born in the German city of [[Bielefeld]] and lived across Germany. He spent two years as a lieutenant in the parachute regiment of the German army before getting his MBA from the Turner College of Business at [[Columbus State University]]. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/fe8f0a4c-fa14-11e2-b8ef-00144feabdc0?_i_location=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/fe8f0a4c-fa14-11e2-b8ef-|title=Enough limelight for both bosses|last=|first=|date=|website=Financial Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-13}}</ref>After graduation, Conze joined [[Procter & Gamble]].
==Career==
===Procter & Gamble=== Conze worked for [[Procter & Gamble]], for 17 years (1993-2010), eventually becoming Marketing Director of Global Skincare from 2000 to 2001. At P&G, he also held the role of Senior Marketing Director of Beauty in Greater China from 2004 to 2007. Following stints in the UK, Switzerland, US and China, he left P&G as Managing Director of DACH in 2010. For Conze this experience taught him the importance of innovation and geographic breadth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/fe8f0a4c-fa14-11e2-b8ef-00144feabdc0|title=Enough limelight for both bosses|last=|first=|date=|website=Financial Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-18}}</ref>
===Dyson=== Conze joined Dyson as President, North America in 2010 and in September 2011 Conze succeeded Martin McCourt as Chief Executive Officer of Dyson.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/industry/9075642/Interview-Dyson-CEO-Max-Conze-Our-lifeblood-is-inventing.-That-is-where-we-spend-all-of-our-money..html|title=Interview Dyson CEO Max Conze: 'Our lifeblood is inventing. That is where we spend all of our money.'|last=Ahmed|first=Kamal|date=2012-02-11|access-date=2017-09-15|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> He had been inspired by James Dyson’s story and the two operated hand in hand harmoniously.
Dyson saw its sales revenue doubled and investment in new technology increased to 3 times during Max’s term.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?__biz=MjAzNzMzNTkyMQ==&mid=2653757260&idx=1&sn=966d8e3626b28eb955cf96add2ba3aaa&scene=0|title=Exclusive Interview with CEO of Dyson Max Conze|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Conze ran a group with more than 4,400 employees around the world including the UK head office; a Malaysian factory where the bulk of production is carried out, a second technology campus named Hullavington in Malmesbury and a new motor facility in Singapore. Under Conze’s leadership, Dyson experienced strong growth and entered new categories.
2016 saw the launch of the Dyson Supersonic hair dryer, the Dyson V8 cord-free vacuum and the introduction of the Dyson Demo shop. Dyson's then-CEO Max Conze said, “2016 was one of our best years yet, driven by new technology and international growth. Our future is best understood by looking at the new Dyson demo stores. They get people hands-on with Dyson machines to understand the intelligent technology inside.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://applianceretailer.com.au/2017/03/dyson-records-30-growth-australia/#.WZa38GcUnIU|title=Dyson grows by one third in Australia - Appliance Retailer|date=2017-03-29|work=Appliance Retailer|access-date=2017-09-15|language=en-US}}</ref>
Conze led Dyson through a period of expansion, announcing the new Hullavington campus in February 2017 as a part of plans to increase the company’s workforce of engineers and scientists to around 7000 in the next five years.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://inews.co.uk/essentials/news/business/dyson-bags-record-profits-thanks-299-hairdryer/|title=Dyson's £299 'despite Brexit' hairdryer sees huge profit increase|date=2017-03-27|work=iNews|access-date=2017-09-15|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In March 2017, Dyson revealed that its profits for 2016 topped £630 million after company recorded a 244 percent growth in China markets.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cityam.com/264642/sir-james-dyson-set-spend-130m-snap-up-village-130m|title=James Dyson is planning to spend £130m to hoover up these London buildings|last=Chopra|first=Shruti Tripathi|date=2017-05-14|access-date=2017-09-15|language=en}}</ref> Dyson announced a £1.5bn investment into research and development of future technologies.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.welt.de/wirtschaft/article136209448/Diese-Staubsauger-machen-die-Deutschen-gluecklich.html|title=Dyson stellt neuen Staubsauger vor|last=|first=|date=|work=DIE WELT|access-date=2017-09-15|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> The plan was rooted in an ongoing expansion of Dyson engineering, working with universities to develop a technology pipeline that stretches 25 years into the future. Conze is passionate about the potential of young people and the benefits of recruiting talent fresh out of university, believing that they are more willing to take risks and think unconventionally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/sep/14/sir-james-dyson-upbeat-about-brexit-as-company-invests-in-expansion|title=Sir James Dyson upbeat about Brexit as company invests in expansion|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Conze left Dyson under acrimonious circumstances in October 2017. <ref>{{cite news|last1=Rob Davies|title = Dyson to sue former chief executive Max Conze | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/nov/15/dyson-sue-former-chief-executive-max-conze|accessdate=2 December 2017|publisher=Guardian}}</ref>
===ProSiebenSat.1 Media SE=== Conze joins ProSiebenSat.1 Media SE to the 1st of June as the new CEO. He follows to Thomas Ebeling who left ProSiebenSat.1 on 22nd of February 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.handelsblatt.com/unternehmen/it-medien/neuer-chef-max-conze-soll-prosieben-sat-1-wieder-in-den-dax-fuehren/22349174.html?ticket=ST-1829820-eI5fLcviQM3SNJ06caiD-ap1r|title=Neuer Chef Max Conze soll ProSieben Sat 1 wieder in den Dax führen|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Personal life== Conze is father of two daughters, Lea and Chiara. He lives in Wiltshire, England, and enjoys horse riding with his family, as well as skiing and sailing. He owns a horse, who is also called Max.<ref name="Sharman">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/fe8f0a4c-fa14-11e2-b8ef-00144feabdc0,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2Ffe8f0a4c-fa14-11e2-b8ef-00144feabdc0.html%3Fsiteedition%3Duk&siteedition=uk&_i_referer=#axzz3Q6zFVHsh|title=Enough limelight for both bosses|last=Sharman|first=Andy|date=2013-08-04|publisher=FT.com|accessdate=2015-03-13}}</ref>

'''Maxim Behar''' ({{lang-bg|Максим Бехар}}; {{lang-he|מקסים בכר}}) is a [[Bulgaria|Bulgarian]] businessman of [[History of the Jews in Bulgaria|Jewish]] descent.<ref name="ajc.org">[http://www.ajc.org/site/c.ffITK0OyFoG/b.8390511/k.CD4B/Greetings_from_Bulgarian_Jewish_Leader_Maxim_Behar.htm Greetings from Bulgarian Jewish Leader Maxim Behar]</ref> He is the CEO and Chairman of the Board of [[M3 Communications Group, Inc]],<ref name="communications1">{{cite web|url=http://m3bg.com/ |title=M3 Communications Group, Inc. - The PR Experts |publisher=M3bg.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-27}}</ref> a public relations and public affairs company and a [[Hill+Knowlton Strategies]] partner since 2000. Behar is also president of the International Communications Consultancy Organization,<ref>[http://news.iccopr.com/icco-appoints-maxim-behar-as-president/ ICCO appoints Maxim Behar as President]</ref> board member of PR Museum in New York,<ref>[http://www.iccopr.com/2016/09/icco-president-appointed-to-the-board-of-pr-museum/ ICCO President appointed to the Board of PR Museum]</ref> and a frequent speaker<ref>[http://www.forumdavos.com/people/2/Maxim+Behar Annual Globul Forum "Communication on the top"]</ref> at national and international events. He is also Chairman of the Board of World Communications Forum in Davos.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=149167|title=Bulgaria's Behar Becomes Chairman of Davos' PR Forum|publisher=|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref>
==Life and career==
===Journalism=== * 1985-1989: Correspondent of ''Rabotnichesko delo'' daily in Shumen, Bulgaria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.segabg.com/article.php?id=231237 |title=Максим и Мила Бехар - 20 години живот по редакциите |publisher=segabg.com |date= |accessdate=2015-02-02}}</ref> * 1989-1991: Correspondent of Rabotnichesko delo daily in Warsaw, Poland. * 1992-1995: Co-founder of the ''Standard'' Daily,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://standartnews.com/ |title=Информационна агенция Стандарт Нюз и вестник Стандарт - новини, анализи, коментари, интервюта за икономика, бизнес, общество, политика, технологии, спорт, култура, стил, здраве |publisher=Standartnews.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-27}}</ref> one of the first private daily newspapers in Bulgaria, where he was the Managing Editor.
===Businesses=== * 1994: Founded [[M3 Communications Group, Inc]].<ref name="communications1"/> * 2003: Co-founder and shareholder, with former Nevada Governor [[Bob Miller (Nevada governor)|Bob Miller]], of a Bulgarian-American consultancy company Miller & Behar Strategies.<ref>{{cite web|author=M3 Communications Group, Inc. |url=http://millerandbehar.com/ |title=MB Strategies Limited |publisher=Millerandbehar.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-27}}</ref> * 2003: Founder and Chairman of the Board of M3 Communications College,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m3college.com/ |title=M3 Communications College |publisher=M3college.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-27}}</ref> the first and the only fully licensed college in Bulgaria of Public communication studies, now associated with the Manhattan Institute of Management<ref>{{cite web|author=The Manhattan Institute of Management |url=http://mimusa.org/ |title=Welcome to the Manhattan Institute of Management |publisher=Mimusa.org |date= |accessdate=2012-09-27}}</ref> in New York.
===Education=== * 1983: Graduated international economic relations at the [[University of Economics, Prague|Prague Economic University]]. * 1999: Graduated the Full Corporate Program of Japanese Style of Management, AOTS,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aots.or.jp/eng/t_prg_j/management/fy/index.html/ |title=HIDA - Training Programs - Outline of Management Training |publisher=Aots.or.jp |date= |accessdate=2012-09-27}}</ref> Yokohama Kenshu Center, Japan. * 2011: Executive Management Training at the [[Pacific Institute]] by Lou Tice in Seattle, WA
==Executive positions and organizational memberships== * 1997-2000: Board member and Executive Director for the Bulgarian Investment Forum. * 1999-2012: Member of the Boards of Junior Achievement Bulgaria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bulgaria.ja-ye.org/ |title=JA Bulgaria |publisher=Bulgaria.ja-ye.org |date= |accessdate=2012-09-27}}</ref> * 1999-current: Full member of the International Public Relations Association. * 2001-2007: President of the Bulgarian Business Leaders Forum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bblf.bg/members/honorary |title=Bulgarian Business Leaders Forum Honorary Board|publisher=Bblf.bg |date= |accessdate=2015-11-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bblf.bg/board |title=Bulgarian Business Leaders Forum Board|publisher=Bblf.bg |date= |accessdate=2015-11-02}}</ref> * 2002-current: Founder and Chairman of the Bulgarian-Polish Business Club. * 2002-current: Founding member of the Board of Trustees of Every Child Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://detebg.org/ |title=For Our Children Foundation |publisher=detebg.org |date= |accessdate=2012-09-27}}</ref> * 2003-2011: Member of the Central Israelite Spiritual Council in Bulgaria.<ref name="ajc.org"/> * 2005-current: Full member of the Public Relations Society of America<ref>{{cite web|url=http://prsa.org/ |title=Public Relations Resources & PR Tools for Communications Professionals: Public Relations Society of America |publisher=PRSA |date= |accessdate=2012-09-27}}</ref> * 2005-current: Vice-President of the Atlantic Club in Bulgaria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://atlantic-club.org/index.php?en_board-of-directors |title=Atlantic Club in Bulgaria Board of Directors |publisher=www.atlantic-club.org |date= |accessdate=2015-11-02}}</ref> * 2012-current: Chairman at Hill+Knowlton Strategies, Czech Republic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hkstrategies.cz/cs/Kontakty/Maxim-Behar |title=Hill + Knowlton Strategies - Czech Republic |publisher=Hillandknowlton.cz |date= |accessdate=2015-10-31}}</ref>
==Diplomatic service== * 2004: Appointed as [[Honorary Consul]] of the Republic of [[Seychelles]] to Bulgaria.<ref>{{cite web|author=M3 Communications Group, Inc. |url=http://seychelles.bg/index.php?lang=en |title=Consulate of the Republic of Seychelles|publisher=Seychelles.bg |date= |accessdate=2015-10-31}}</ref>
==Awards and recognition== * 2005: Honorary citizen of [[Shumen]].<ref>[http://www.bulphoto.com/events/4068/ Maxim Behar given the keys to city of Shumen (in Bulgarian)]</ref> * 2012: The Bulgarian monthly Economy magazine<ref>[http://economymagazine.bg Economy Magazine] (in Bulgarian)</ref> presented its yearly award to Maxim Behar for achievements in Business Communications. * 2012: Named "Manager of the year" in an independent online vote by the Bulgarian Manager magazine and TV Channel bTV.<ref name="btv_winner">{{cite web|url=http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=148184|title=Bulgarian PR Expert Maxim Behar on European Business Awards Jury|publisher=|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> * 2012: The Association of Business Communications of India announced Behar as "Communicator of the Decade".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abci.in/index.htm|title=Association of Business Communicators of India - ABCI|publisher=|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> * 2015: The Gold Stevie Award.<ref>[http://www.stevieawards.com/pubs/iba/awards/408_2950_25808.cfm 2015 Management Awards Category Stevie® Award Winners]</ref>

'''Michel P. Fribourg''' (1913 - 10 April 2001) was a Belgian-born Jewish-American billionaire businessman, the chairman and CEO of [[ContiGroup Companies|Continental Grain]], a global agribusiness and food company founded by Simon Fribourg in Arlon, Belgium in 1813. In his ''[[New York Times]]'' obituary, he was called "certainly the premier figure in world trade in food of the 20th century".<ref name="nytimes1" />
==Early life== Fribourg was born in Antwerp and educated in France.<ref name="nytimes1">{{cite web|author=JOHN SCHWARTZ|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/12/business/michel-fribourg-87-trader-who-opened-soviet-market.html |title=Michel Fribourg, 87, Trader Who Opened Soviet Market - The New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=12 April 2001 |accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref><ref name="Klarsfeld1">{{cite book|author=Beate Klarsfeld / Serge Klarsfeld |title= Mémoires |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iHXjBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT331&lpg=PT331&dq=Michel+Fribourg+juif&source=bl&ots=839SQUagHB&sig=O0XzzgurqmAslDoRPLwkV0yPIWw&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjm--qek83VAhUCLlAKHUOADxQQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Michel%20Fribourg%20juif&f=false|year=2015|publisher=Flammarion|isbn=978-2-08132-399-5}}</ref>
==Career== He worked all of his life for [[ContiGroup Companies|Continental Grain]] a company owned by his family, rising to chairman and CEO.<ref name="nytimes1"/>
In 1944, following the death of his father, he became the fifth generation of Fribourgs to lead Continental Grain.<ref name="nytimes1"/>
In 1998, ''[[Forbes]]'' estimated his net worth at $2.4 billion, based on his ownership of Continental Grain and 75% of ContiFinancial.<ref name="forbes1998"/>
==Personal life== He was married to Mary Ann.<ref name="nytimes2001">{{cite news|author=|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/12/classified/paid-notice-deaths-fribourg-michel-p.html |title=Paid Notice: Deaths FRIBOURG, MICHEL. P. - The New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=12 April 2001 |accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref>
They had five children, sons Robert Fribourg, [[Paul J. Fribourg]], Charles Fribourg, Nadine Newman and Caroline Rosen.<ref name="nytimes2001"/>
He died in New York on 10 April 2001.<ref name="nytimes1"/>

==Manufacturing conditions== Mikasa manufactures products in [[Thailand]] and has been accused of [[workplace bullying|workplace brutality]] and [[human rights]] violations in some factories. The [[International Trade Union Confederation]], published a report alleging "systematic anti-union campaigns" by Mikasa.<ref name="ituc">2007 Annual Survey of violations of trade union rights - Thailand: Violations in 2006, International Trade Union Confederation, 2007, [http://survey07.ituc-csi.org/getcountry.php?IDCountry=THA&IDLang=EN survey07.ituc-csi.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726195904/http://survey07.ituc-csi.org/getcountry.php?IDCountry=THA&IDLang=EN |date=2011-07-26 }}</ref> The report detailed various allegations: {{cquote|Supervisors intensively monitored and penalised union leaders through discriminatory transfers and disciplinary procedures for trumped up infractions. Union committee members were prevented from working overtime, compelled to take unpaid leave, separated from their fellow workers, and publicly humiliated by senior managers, in one case destroying their work then ordering them to fix it. When three union committee members publicly protested against the factory’s actions against workers, the management sued them in court for defamation.
When a union committee member who was pregnant [[miscarriage|miscarried]] during her day shift at the factory, she requested the factory to send her to a local hospital. Management refused, and instead sent her to the medical room at the factory, where she was forced to wait until the evening when a friend from another factory came and took her to hospital for treatment.<ref name="ituc" />}} Through such practices, the ITUC argued, Mikasa succeeded in either firing or forcing the resignation of the entire union committee (except the union president), essentially destroying the [[labor rights|right of its workers to organize]].
A separate report, by the Thai Labor Campaign alleged that new Mikasa factory workers received only 173 [[baht]] per day ([[USD|$]]4.36 per day) in 2006.<ref name="tlc">The Life of Football Factory Workers in Thailand, Junya Lek Yimprasert, Thai Labor Campaign, June 30, 2006, [http://www.cleanclothes.org/documents/Life_football_workers_of_thailand.pdf PDF from CleanClothes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613061029/http://cleanclothes.org/documents/Life_football_workers_of_thailand.pdf |date=2010-06-13 }}</ref>

'''Mohamed bin Hammam''' ({{lang-ar|محمد بن همّام}}; born 8 May 1949) is a [[Qatari]] who was a football administrator and president of the [[Asian Football Confederation]] from 1 August 2002 to 14 June 2011, and a member of FIFA's 24-man executive committee from 1996 to 2011 for more than 15 years.<ref>[https://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/federation/bodies/exco.html] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528104818/http://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/federation/bodies/exco.html |date=28 May 2010 }}</ref> On 23 July 2011, Bin Hammam was banned for life from all [[FIFA]] and football related activities by an action of the [[FIFA Ethics Committee]].<ref name="independent.co.uk">[https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/bin-hammam-handed-lifetime-ban-from-football-2319420.html Bin Hammam Banned, The Independent, 24 July 2011], The Independent 24 July 2011</ref> Bin Hammam challenged this sanction in the Court of Arbitration for Sport and the ban was subsequently annulled on 19 July 2012 due to lack of sufficient evidence.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18901316|title=BBC Sport - Mohamed Bin Hammam wins appeal against Fifa ban|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref> However, just 5 months later in December 2012, FIFA handed bin Hammam a second life ban from football after "conflicts of interest" were identified in his role as president of the AFC.<ref name="BBC News">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20762363|title=BBC Sport - Fifa ban Mohammed Bin Hammam for life after he quits football|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref>
He was the subject of an [[Investigative journalism|exposé]] published by the British newspaper the ''[[Sunday Times]]'' in June 2014. The newspaper published leaked email documents which showed that bin Hammam had paid members of other nations' Football Associations in the run up to his FIFA presidential election campaign and prior to the [[2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cup bids]] decision that took place in December 2010.
==Early life== He was born on 8 May 1949 in [[Doha]], Qatar. His father was a businessman, and his mother was a nurse. He has eleven children. He worked in Qatar's football confederation from 1972 to 1996.
==Presidency of AFC== During his time at the helm, he oversaw the creation of the [[AFC Champions League]] and the acceptance of [[Football Federation Australia|Australia]] into the AFC. He also initiated the strategic development program called Vision Asia extreme golf club. He has been a [[FIFA]] Executive Member since 1996. He has opposed the participation of the [[Wellington Phoenix FC|Wellington Phoenix]] team in the [[Asian Champions League]]. He was re-elected once again on 5 January 2011.
In March 2011, he called upon [[Arab]] and [[Muslim]] nations to play the [[Palestine national football team]] at the [[Faisal Al-Husseini International Stadium]]: "I hope that all Arab and Muslim teams will come here to play matches against [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] at their own home ground". A number of regional football squads had rejected the idea of playing there as it could be seen as tantamount to accepting the Israeli right to the [[West Bank]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Ezzedine|first=Hossam|title=Thailand defeat Palestine on penalties|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gnysB3qf5FSZhOtoRwomK8RFCV6Q?docId=CNG.2776ffab64034117966c14297a983fe4.2c1|publisher=AFP|accessdate=12 March 2011|date=10 March 2011}}</ref>
As well as being the president of the Asian Football Confederation, he was also the chairman of the Fifa Goal Bureau, whose grants provide financial support for member associations across the world. He was also influential in bringing the [[2022 FIFA World Cup]] to his native Qatar.
===2011 FIFA presidential election=== {{Main|61st FIFA Congress}} In an interview with ''[[The Guardian]]'', Mohammed bin Hammam stated he might run against the incumbent president [[Sepp Blatter]] for the [[List of Presidents of FIFA|presidency of FIFA]] which will be decided during the [[61st FIFA Congress]] between 31 May and 1 June 2011. He told the ''Guardian'': "People have to try change. Change is good."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/mar/10/mohamed-bin-hammam-fifa-presidency | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Matt | last=Scott | title=Mohamed bin Hammam set to run against Sepp Blatter for Fifa presidency | date=10 March 2011}}</ref> Bin Hammam said that Blatter was "an experienced person, he has made significant contribution to football worldwide but I believe there is a time limit for everything. There is now a time for a new face and a new heir."<ref name="hammam-confirms">{{Cite news |date=5 May 2011|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/mar/18/mohamed-bin-hammam-fifa-president|title=Mohamed bin Hammam confirms intention to run for Fifa presidency|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> Bin Hammam had supported Blatter's 1998 and 2002 presidential campaigns but admitted that he had fallen out with Blatter over issues within the [[FIFA Executive Committee]]. In August 2010 Bin Hamman had vowed not to run against Blatter saying that "I will be backing him to remain in office for a new mandate. He is my very good friend".<ref name="said-done">{{Cite news |date=13 March 2011|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/mar/13/fifa-sepp-blatter|title=Said & Done|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref>
Following the 10 May 2011 meeting of the [[Caribbean Football Union|CFU]], [[Chuck Blazer]] a [[FIFA]] Executive Committee member and General Secretary of [[CONCACAF]] initiated an investigation <ref>[http://www.bahamasb2b.com/news/2011/05/bahamian-blows-whistle-on-fifa-corruption-9044.html Bahamian officials alert CONCACAF to bribery allegations], Bahamas B2bB, 31 May 2011</ref> into allegations of attempted bribery despite not being in attendance. As a result of the investigations preliminary findings, Bin Hammam was charged with offering bribes for votes and appeared before FIFA's ethics committee on 29 May. Bin Hammam withdrew from the presidential race the day before the ethics committee meeting, leaving Blatter to run unopposed.<ref name="hammam-withdraws">{{Cite news |date=29 May 2011|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/may/29/mohamed-bin-hammam-withdraws-fifa-race|title=Mohamed bin Hammam withdraws from FIFA presidential race|publisher=The Guardian}}</ref>
On 29 May 2011, FIFA's ethics committee suspended Bin Hammam and [[Jack Warner (football executive)|Jack Warner]] temporarily from all football-related activity pending the outcome of a full inquiry into accusations that they offered financial incentives to members of the [[Caribbean Football Union]].<ref name=ESPN_1>{{cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/924368/sepp-blatter-escapes-as-jack-warner,-mohammed-bin-hammam-suspended|title=Blatter escapes, Bin Hammam banned|date=29 May 2011|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=23 July 2011}}</ref> Bin Hammam said that he would appeal against the committee's decision to provisionally ban him from football related activity, saying that "The way these proceedings have been conducted is not compliant with any principles of justice."<ref name="hammam-appeal">{{Cite news |date=30 May 2011|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/13590264.stm|title=Bin Hammam to appeal against Fifa suspension|publisher=BBC}}</ref> He also issued a statement calling for his reinstatement as well as responding to the claims in detail.
While the appeals process is ongoing, Zhang Jilong is acting President of the Asian Football Confederation.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/news/8545764/Asian-Football-Association-vice-president-Zhang-Jilong-takes-the-reins-from-suspended-Mohamed-bin-Hammam.html Asian Football Association vice-president Zhang Jilong takes the reins from suspended Mohamed bin Hammam, Daily Telegraph, 30 May 2011], Daily Telegraph, 30 May 2011</ref>
On 23 July 2011, Bin Hammam was banned for life from all football activities by a five-member panel of the [[FIFA]] Ethics committee chaired by [[Petrus Damaseb]]. The committee found that his actions violated the organization' ethics rules after studying the reports of investigators and hearing the testimony of witnesses from the May 2011 meeting who were not available for cross examination by Bin Hammam's legal representatives.<ref name="independent.co.uk"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/organisation/bodies/news/newsid=1479068/index.html|title=Ethics Committee bans football officials|date=23 July 2011|work=FIFA.com}}</ref><ref>[http://streamstudio.world-television.com/CCUIv3/streamSelect.aspx?ticket=645-676-10049&target=en-default-&status=ondemand&browser=ns-0-0-0-10-0 Video of Damaseb/Ethics Committee statement on Bin Hamman--FIFA], FIFA Video of bin Hammam Press Conference, 24 July 2011</ref> Bin Hammam appealed against his ban, and was eventually rejected by the FIFA Appeal Committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/aboutfifa/organisation/bodies/news/newsid=1511253/index.html|title=Appeal Committee confirms Ethics Committee decision on Bin Hammam|date=15 September 2011|work=FIFA.com}}</ref>
Bin Hammam took his appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport which heard the appeal on 18–19 April 2012. His lifetime ban was annulled by the court on 19 July 2012.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/><ref>{{cite news| url= http://sports.ndtv.com/football/news/item/193825-bin-hammam-wins-appeal-in-fifa-bribery-case| title= Bin Hammam wins appeal in FIFA bribery case
| date=20 July 2012}}</ref>
In December 2012, FIFA handed bin Hammam a second life ban from football after "conflicts of interest" were identified in his role as president of the AFC.
==Sunday Times exposé== {{Prose|date=November 2015}} {{BLP unsourced section|date=May 2017}} On 1 June 2014 the Sunday Times published leaked emails given to them from a "senior figure inside the sport’s governing body". There were several emails leaked which shown that:
* Two days prior to inviting 25 members of African football associations on an all expenses paid [[Press junket|junket]] to [[Kuala Lumpur]], US $200,000 was withdrawn from the [[Asian Football Confederation]] accounts. * A second junket organised was four months later, guests were encouraged to bring their family and were given $5k spending money * [[National Football Association of Swaziland|Swaziland Football Association]] president [[Adam Mthehwa]] requested a $30k payment as his "gratuity will only be paid to me when I reach the age of 55 in 2010" * Mohammed bin Hammam arranged for the delivery of sixty tickets for matches at the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] (valued at £3,800) to [[Fédération Camerounaise de Football|Cameroonian Football Federation]] President [[Issa Hayatou]] * [[Fadoul Houssein]], president of the [[Fédération Djiboutienne de Football|Djibouti Football Association]], emailed him to that he was "sure" bin Hammam would win the{{clarify|date=May 2017|reason=missing words?}} and received $30k to fund "expensive medical treatment" for his association’s general secretary. * Mohammed bin Hammam asked the [[Sudan Football Association]] to provide details to make a payment after they claimed to not be able to afford to pay the general assembly * [[Seedy Kinteh]], the president of the [[Gambia Football Association]] was paid $10k. Kinteh implied that the money was paid in exchange for a vote to become president of FIFA when he signed off the email: "I have every reason to be grateful and indeed my President and Brother I AM !!!!". Kinteh later received $50k for a new [[car]] paid through bin Hammam's daughter's account. * Mohammed bin Hammam paid [[Manuel Dende]], the [[São Toméan Football Federation|Sao Tome FA]] president $50k, after Dende initially requesting $232k. * Paid [[Izetta Wesley]], the [[Liberia Football Association|Liberian FA]] president, $10k, * Paid [[Kalusha Bwalya]] $50k for his "football association and personal expenditures" on a trip to Doha. * Paid controlled FIFA's Goal programme and paid $400k to the African [[FIFA Executive Committee|FIFA Executive members']] Football Associations (Cameroon, Nigeria and Ivory Coast) * Paid $50k to [[Namibia Football Association]] to assist with "second division leagues that went crippled by the prevailing global economic melt down." * Paid [[Somali Football Federation]] $100k through his daughter's account * Paid [[CECAFA]] $200k three days after the World Cup bids had been decided to fund the [[2010 CECAFA Cup]], a tournament that is played by East African national teams. * [[Ganesh Thapa]], president of the [[All Nepal Football Association|Nepalese FA]], was paid a total of £115,000 from two separate accounts of Bin Hammam's company Kemco, in March and August 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nepalnews.com/index.php/sports-archive/35411-uk-based-newspaper-says-anfa-prez-thapa-received-%C2%A3115,000-from-hammam|title=UK based newspaper says ANFA prez Thapa received £115,000 from Hammam|publisher=|accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref>

The '''Nine-Twelve District''' is a major area of [[downtown Cleveland]], in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Ohio]], that is the re-branding of the former Financial District of Cleveland.<ref>http://www.downtowncleveland.com/development/ninetwelve-district.aspx ''Nine Twelve District'' Retrieved on 2015-08-26.</ref> This re-branding has largely been championed by the [[Downtown Cleveland Alliance]]. The name refers to the two major commercial avenues between which the district lies, East 9th Street and East 12th Street. This revamping and reboot of the Cleveland [[Central Business District]] has occurred because property and business owners have sought to put a new face on the heart of the city.<ref>http://www.cleveland.com/business/index.ssf/2013/09/a_time_of_change_for_downtown.html ''Downtown Cleveland's Changing Face'' Retrieved on 2015-08-26</ref> The district is home to the newly expanded [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio|Cuyahoga County]] Headquarters. [[File:Cuyahoga1.jpg|300px|right|thumbnail|The Cuyahoga County Headquarters Building]]
Part of this re-imagining of the area has been Walnut Wednesdays and the success of this has attracted over a 1,000 people to the side street in the Nine-Twelve with its assortment of food trucks and office-worker lunch-break social events.<ref>http://blog.cleveland.com/downtown_cleveland_alliance/2015/05/downtowns_ninetwelve_district.html ''Downtown's Nine Twelve District is Cleveland's Latest Success Story'' Retrieved on 2015-08-26</ref> This has in turn led to a growing interest and more importantly growing investment in the area. This can be seen in the rehabbing of [[The 9 Cleveland]] into the Metropolitan Hotel and [[Heinen's Fine Foods]] opening a store in the old [[Swetland Building (Cleveland)|Swetland Building]]. <ref>http://www.metropolitancleveland.com/ ''the 9'' Retrieved on 2015-08-26</ref> The effort of the [[Downtown Cleveland Alliance]] has also led to an increase in the occupancy of downtown buildings and the refurbishing of old office buildings into residential properties; this can be exemplified by the [[1717 East Ninth Building]], the [[Statler Arms Apartments]] and the current renovation of the Scholfield Building into a high-end hotel.<ref>http://www.residencesat1717.com/ ''Luxury with a View'' Retrieved on 2015-08-26</ref>
The next big question for the district will be how to re-envision the largely vacant [[The 925 Building]] as [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]]-based [[Huntington Bank]] has by now moved to [[200 Public Square]] into the former [[BP]] Tower.<ref>http://blog.cleveland.com/business/2008/11/huntington_moving_to_200_publi.html ''Huntington Moving to What Was the BP Tower'' Retrieved on 2015-08-26</ref> This has led to one of the largest office spaces in downtown to now sit empty while investors rally to be in on the next big thing in Cleveland's Nine-Twelve District. The most recent plans call for a mixture of retail, residential, and commercial square footage for the mammoth building. This plan is being spearheaded by South [[Florida]] developer Andrew "Avi" Greenbaum.<ref>http://therealdeal.com/miami/blog/2015/08/09/2nd-south-florida-buyer-bets-on-cleveland-landmark/ ''Second SoFla Buyer Bets on Cleveland landmark'' Retrieved on 2015-08-26</ref> Only time will tell if these new out-of-state investors can resurrect the once highly sought-after office space in Ohio.

'''Ope Banwo''' is a USA-based Nigerian attorney and entrepreneur. He is known for his work with Daniel Ademinokan on the movie ''Ghetto Dreamz,'' nominated for Best Original Screenplay/Scriptwriting in the [[2012 Nollywood Movies Awards|2012 Nollywood Movie Awards]]. He has also created software, Mobimatic'','' for creating mobile apps.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://dailypost.ng/2017/07/19/ope-banwo-returns-bang-launches-wonder-mobile-app-building-software-lagos/|title=Ope Banwo returns with a Bang! Launches Wonder Mobile App Building Software in Lagos - Daily Post Nigeria|date=2017-07-19|work=Daily Post Nigeria|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
More recently, he launched a [[cryptocurrency]] startup, Nollytainment Limited, which seeks to use [[Blockchain|blockchain technology]] to support [[Nollywood]], the Nigerian movie industry.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2018/03/10/nollycoin-ico-gets-major-boost-with-several-celebrity-endorsements/|title=Nollycoin ICO Gets Major Boost with several Celebrity Endorsements - THISDAYLIVE|date=2018-03-10|work=THISDAYLIVE|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
He is married to Olunike Ajoke Olunloyo and they have 4 children together.
== Early life and education == Ope Banwo was born in the Fadeyi area of Lagos, Nigeria on April 30, 1964 to Mr. Omotayo Odukoya Banwo and Mrs. Comfort Adedoja Banwo.
He attended Fadeyi Primary school in Fadeyi and [[Ijebu Ode Grammar School|Ijebu-Ode Grammar School]]. Banwo graduated as a lawyer from [[Obafemi Awolowo University]] and soon afterwards, obtained a [[Master's degree|Master's Degree]] in law from the [[University of Lagos]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/01/lagos-big-boy-ope-banwo-still-showbiz/|title=Is Lagos big boy, Ope Banwo still in showbiz? - Vanguard News|date=2017-01-13|work=Vanguard News|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Business career == Banwo was the first MD/CEO of Dove Media, the media network operated by the [[Redeemed Christian Church of God]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.modernghana.com/movie/386/dove-media-set-to-release-nigerias-first-biographical-movie.html|title=DOVE MEDIA SET TO RELEASE NIGERIA’S FIRST BIOGRAPHICAL MOVIE|work=Modern Ghana|access-date=2018-05-06|language=en-gb}}</ref> Afterwards, Banwo continued his career in the entertainment industry by launching his own record label, Stingomania Records.<ref name=":0" />
Dr. Ope Banwo is also the Chairman/Chief Executive Officer of Afrinet Business Solutions, an outfit that provides internet business solutions to businesses in Africa and non-African companies doing or seeking to do business in Africa using the power of the internet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanguardngr.com/2014/07/internet-holds-key-nigerias-unemployment-problem/|title=‘Internet holds key to Nigeria's unemployment problem’ - Vanguard News|date=2014-07-14|work=Vanguard News|access-date=2018-05-30|language=en-US}}</ref>
He is also a founding partner at ''Banwo & Igbokwe''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://banwoandigbokwe.com/partners/|title=Partners {{!}} Banwo & Igbokwe|website=banwoandigbokwe.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-30}}</ref> law firm in Omaha, Nebraska, USA.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.legaldirectories.com/s-NE-Omaha-Atty-1~I.aspx|title=Find Lawyer, Attorney, Law Firms, Attorneys, Legal Information. LegalDirectories.com|website=www.legaldirectories.com|access-date=2018-05-30}}</ref>
== Awards == Ope Banwo won the Los Angeles Movie Awards in 2011 for the movie, "''Ghetto Dreams."'' An award of excellence under the Script Category.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thelamovieawards.com/2011_(I)_Winners.html|title=2011 (I) Winners|website=thelamovieawards.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-28}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=October 2009}} [[File:Automotive_News_PACE_Award_Trophy.jpg|left|thumb|PACE Award Trophy]]The '''PACE Award''' ('''P'''remier '''A'''utomotive Suppliers’ '''C'''ontribution to '''E'''xcellence '''Award''') is an annual award from [[Automotive News]] in collaboration with [[Ernst & Young]] and through 2016 the Transportation Research Center Inc. (TRC Inc.). For the 2016-17 awards OESA, the Original Equipment Suppliers Association, will be a sponsor alongside EY. Automotive News and EY founded the award to celebrate innovation, technological advancement and business performance among automotive suppliers. It is given annually since 1995 in a black-tie ceremony the week of the SAE (Society of Automotive Engineers) convention in Detroit.
The focus of the award is an innovation developed primarily by a supplier, that is new to the automotive industry, that is in use, and that "changes the rules of the game." Awards have been given for products, materials, processes, capital equipment and services. A panel of independent judges from industry, finance, research, and academia choose finalists from the initial applicants, make site visits to evaluate the innovation, and then gather to select winners, independent of the sponsors. Winners to date include suppliers from Japan, Korea, the US, Canada, Brazil and an array of European countries.<ref>{{cite web| title = About the PACE Awards | work=PACE 2013| accessdate = 2013-04-11| url = https://www.paceaward.com/docs/about.cfm}}</ref> Among the most awarded companies over the years are [[BorgWarner]], [[Delphi Automotive]], [[Federal-Mogul]] and [[PPG Industries]] as well as [[Robert Bosch GmbH]], [[Gentex Corporation]], [[Johnson Controls]] and [[Siemens AG]].<ref>{{cite web| title = Past Winners| work=Automotive News| accessdate = 2013-04-12| url = http://www.autonews.com/Assets/html/pace_award/past_winners.html }}</ref>
{{TOC right}}

revision.text:
'''Sam Pa''' is believed to be the head of the 88 Queensway Group and numerous subsidiary companies that operate mining and resource concessions in a number of countries notably across Africa. Pa has also been the subject of controversy, allegedly propping up [[Robert Mugabe]]'s [[ZANU-PF]] regime in Zimbabwe and securing business contacts on the back of a coup d'état in Madagascar and civil unrest in Guinea.
==History== Sam Pa is alleged to use a number of different aliases; at least eight different names were listed in connection with Pa in an American Congressional report.<ref name="e">[https://www.uscc.gov/sites/default/files/Research/The_88_Queensway_Group.pdf 88 Queensway Group, A Case Study in Chinese Investors' Operations in Angola and Beyond]. US -China Economic & Security Review Commission. Levkowitz, McLellan Ross & Warner 10 July 2009</ref> Some of the names used are Sam Pa, Sampa, Samo, Sam King, Sa Muxu, Xu Songhua, Xu Jinghua, Ghui Ka Leung.
It is unknown why Pa uses so many aliases. Attempts to research Pa's history prove inconclusive, which has led some to the belief that he is a "princeling"—the son of a well connected original Chinese communist revolutionary.<ref name=zanu>[http://www.zimdiaspora.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5211:zanu-pf-in-shadow-of-elusive-chinese-magnate&catid=38:travel-tips&Itemid=18 ZANU in shadow of elusive Chinese magnate], ''The Times'' (RSA)</ref> Reports also list one of Pa's aliases as having a Russian military background <ref name=deb>Deborah Brautigam, The Dragons Gift p372</ref> that spent time in Angola during the [[Angolan Civil War]].<ref name=garnaut>[http://www.smh.com.au/business/state-or-mate-whos-behind-china-fund-20100316-qco5.html State or Mate? Who's behind China Fund?], John Garnaut</ref> It is believed that during Pa's time with the Russian military he first met the future Angolan President [[Jose Eduardo Dos Santos]].<ref name=deb/> This was a relationship that he exploited after the Civil War to secure a monopoly over reconstruction projects, which in turn allowed Pa to develop his business interests in China buying a host of construction businesses such as China Steel 20 (Zhongtie 20), Guangxi Construction and Engineering, Guangxi Water and Electric, Sichuan Nanchong, Sichuan Uingshan, Fuikan Ningde, Jinghend INternational and others.<ref>Blog entry 02/10/1007 http://www.chineseinafrica.com</ref> It is also alleged by Chinese bloggers that Pa provided weapons and support during the [[Angolan Civil War]].<ref name="africawindows.com">Luping 01/18/2007 http://www.africawindows.com</ref>
==Current situation==
Sam Pa is said to be the President of the [[China International Fund]] (CIF)<ref name="guinee24.com">Le Patron de la China International Fund chez le Premier Minister: des beaux jours qui s'annoncent pour les secteurs energeique et minier guineens http://www.guinee24.com/index.php?id=5&no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=3619&cHash=c5b55b2237aee7c87fd72a10a112609a</ref> and named by an American Congressional report to be involved in what the report dubbed the "88 Queensway Group" of businesses. This is not the legal name of the group, but rather a nickname referring to the fact that all the businesses were registered at a [[company formation]] agent's offices in Two [[Pacific Place (Hong Kong)|Pacific Place]], 88 [[Queensway, Hong Kong|Queensway]], [[Admiralty, Hong Kong]].<ref name=e/> Some of the businesses associated with the 88 Queensway Group include China Sonangol, Dayuan International (formerly Beiya International) and No 20 China Railways Bureau.<ref name=vines>Alex Vines, Lillian Wong, Markus Weimer and Indira Campos. Royal Institute of International Affairs (Chatham House): [http://www.chathamhouse.org.uk/files/14524_r0809_africanoil.pdf Thirst for African Oil] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091009102912/http://www.chathamhouse.org.uk/files/14524_r0809_africanoil.pdf |date=2009-10-09 }}. Asian National Oil Companies in Nigeria and Angola.</ref> However, it is unclear exactly how many businesses are involved in the 88 Queensway Group with over 30 companies registered to the same address with operations throughout Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America, Southeast Asia and the United States.
Pa's involvement is often not listed in any company documents,<ref name=zanu/> but in a common offshore company formation practice he lists the woman believed to be his wife, Veronica Fung, as director in his place.<ref name=zanu/> Veronica Fung is listed as Director for at least 24 companies, including CIF and China Sonangol.<ref name=zanu/> Alongside Veronica Fung, Pa is also aided by the husband and wife team, Lo Fung Hung and Wang Xiangfei, who also hold directorships on a number of Queensway businesses.<ref name=vines/> Despite their titles of Director, Lo and Wang have been described as "puppets" controlled by Pa.<ref name=garnaut/>
As head of the [[China International Fund]], Pa has traveled to a number of countries meeting high-ranking officials and Presidents. Some noteworthy inclusions are his connections to Angolan President [[José Eduardo dos Santos]],<ref name=deb/> Zimbabwean President [[Robert Mugabe]],<ref name=zanu/> Venezuelan President [[Hugo Chávez]], Argentinean President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]]<ref name=vines/> and Guinean Prime Minister [[Jean-Marie Dore]].<ref name="guinee24.com"/> It is also believed the Pa and CIF have business connections in Tanzania and Madagascar.<ref name=zanu/> Often Pa begin State level relationships at a time when a country is experiencing domestic troubles. For example, on 28 September 2009, 150 unarmed pro-democracy Guinean protestors were massacred by Guinean government troops - a week later CIF negotiated a US$7 billion deal with the regime. A similar situation occurred in Madagascar following a coup. It is thought that Pa, through CIF and its associated companies, has committed upwards of US$20 billion in investment funds, mainly in unstable African dictatorships.<ref name=garnaut/>
One particular political connection Pa tries to keep quiet is that of his connections to the Chinese State. Commentators have stated that Pa and CIF's programmes "must have been approved by the Chinese Government".<ref name=deb/> CIF and Sam Pa are positioned as a key interface in the relationship between the Angolan and Chinese states and the control of Angolan resources - all Angolan oil contracts for the Chinese State company [[Sinopec]] are controlled by CIF.<ref name=vines/>
One of Pa's "puppet" directors, Wang Xiangfei, was previously a director of the China Everbright Group and currently is a non-executive director of China International Trust and Investment Company ([[CITIC Group]]), both state-owned companies in the People's Republic of China. Both China Everbright and CITIC are believed to be subordinate corporations of the PRC Ministry of State Security's Commission of Science, Technology and Industry for National Defense (COTSIND).<ref>Dr Howard DeVore: China's Intelligence and Internal Security Forces</ref>
Another Director, Wu Yang, of at least 14 companies with Pa and the 88 Queensway Group has links to the Chinese PRC Ministry of Public Security and Chinese Ministry of State Security.<ref name=e/> On company filings, Mr Wu Yang lists his residential address as "No.14 Dong Chang An Street, Beijing, China." This address is the headquarters for the Ministry of Public Safety (MPS), a domestic security service of the Chinese Government. Also located in this compound is a reception office for the Ministry of State Security (MSS), the primary state agency responsible for foreign intelligence activities.<ref name=e/>
==Controversy== Sam Pa has been the subject of numerous press and internet blog reporting and his ties to [[Robert Mugabe]]'s ZANU-PF were revealed in the Johannesburg Sunday Times.<ref name=zanu /> It is alleged that in return for diamonds and mineral resources to supply China's booming economy, Pa has provided funds and equipment to the secretive Zimbabwe [[Central Intelligence Organisation]] (CIO) to enable it to deliver an electoral victory for Mugabe and his party.<ref name=zanu /> Pa allegedly had been underwriting operations for the Zimbabwean Secret Service to influence the outcomes of polls in favor of ZANU-PF <ref name=zanu /> and thereby further secure his business dealings in Zimbabwe. In early 2010 Sam Pa offered to match the salaries of the entire Zimbabwean Secret Service, Police and Army to ensure their support for ZANU-PF.<ref name=zanu /> In return, Pa's joint venture with the Zimbabwean Secret Service, Sino-Zim Development, was listed at the top of a classified ZANU-PF list of "special national interest projects".<ref name=zanu />
Sam Pa and his business such as CIF, China Sonangol and Sino-Zimbabwe have often been disassociated from by official Chinese representation. Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhao Zing discouraged Argentinean President Kirchner from entering into any agreements with Sam Pa associated business.<ref name=vines /> The WikiLeak 'Cablegate' affair revealed that Chinese Ambassador to Angola Bolum Zhang also distanced himself from CIF stating CIF's "weak management and lack of leadership have stalled many... projects".<ref>[[WikiLeaks]]: [[United States diplomatic cables leak|cablegate]], cable 2009-01-27 (ID: 09LUANDA51) [http://213.251.145.96/cable/2009/01/09LUANDA51.html NEW CHINA CREDIT LINE UNDER CONSIDERATION] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20101213001027/http://213.251.145.96/cable/2009/01/09LUANDA51.html |date=2010-12-13 }}, Retrieved 2010-12-19.</ref>
CIF and China Sonangol have had reports on their ability to plan and complete some of their projects due to difficulty in raising funds.<ref name=vines /> Pa's work in Angola has been heavily criticised for non-completion, with some saying the Pa's companies were "just playing a game and in the eyes of the Angolan Government have gone through process from belief to feeling cheated".<ref name="africawindows.com" /> Sam Pa's work on recontrusting the Benguela railway line attracted criticism from Angolan locals who quoted "The Chinese spent months getting the camp together and bringing in brand-new bulldozers. Then instead of beginning to repair the line, they dismantled it all, ate their dogs and left." <ref>Michel Serge: When China met Africa. http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2008/04/10/when_china_met_africa</ref>

'''Social media use by businesses''' includes a range of applications. Although [[social media]] accessed via [[desktop computer]]s offer a variety of opportunities for companies in a wide range of [[business sector]]s, mobile social media, which users can access when they are "on the go" via [[tablet computer]]s or [[smartphone]]s, benefit companies because of the location- and time-sensitive awareness of their users. Mobile social media tools can be used for [[marketing research]], communication, [[sales promotion]]s/discounts, informal employee learning/organizational development, relationship development/[[loyalty program]]s,<ref>Kaplan, Andreas M. (March–April 2012). "If you love something, let it go mobile: Mobile marketing and mobile social media 4x4". Business Horizons. 55 (2): 129–139. doi:10.1016/j.bushor.2011.10.009.</ref> and e-commerce. * [[Marketing research]]: Mobile social media applications provide companies data about offline consumer movements at a level of detail that was previously accessible to online companies only. These applications allow any business to know the exact time a customer who uses social media entered one of its locations, as well as know the social media comments made during the visit.<ref>Kaplan, Andreas M. (March–April 2012). "If you love something, let it go mobile: Mobile marketing and mobile social media 4x4". Business Horizons. 55 (2): 129–139. doi:10.1016/j.bushor.2011.10.009.</ref> * [[Communication]]: Mobile social media communication takes two forms: company-to-consumer (in which a company may establish a connection to a consumer based on its location and provide reviews about locations nearby) and user-generated content. For example, McDonald's offered $5 and $10 gift-cards to 100 users randomly selected among those checking in at one of its restaurants. This promotion increased check-ins by 33% (from 2,146 to 2,865), resulted in over 50 articles and blog posts, and prompted several hundred thousand news feeds and Twitter messages.<ref>Kaplan, Andreas M. (March–April 2012). "If you love something, let it go mobile: Mobile marketing and mobile social media 4x4". Business Horizons. 55 (2): 129–139. doi:10.1016/j.bushor.2011.10.009.</ref> * Sales promotions and discounts: Although customers have had to use printed coupons in the past, mobile social media allows companies to tailor promotions to specific users at specific times. For example, when launching its California-Cancun service, [[Virgin America]] offered users who checked in through [[Loopt]] at one of three designated taco trucks in San Francisco or Los Angeles between 11 a.m. and 3 p.m. on August 31, 2010, two tacos for $1 and two flights to [[Cancun]] or [[Cabo San Lucas|Cabo]] for the price of one.<ref>Kaplan, Andreas M. (March–April 2012). "If you love something, let it go mobile: Mobile marketing and mobile social media 4x4". Business Horizons. 55 (2): 129–139. doi:10.1016/j.bushor.2011.10.009.</ref> This special promotion was only available to people who were at a certain location at a certain time. * Relationship development and loyalty programs: In order to increase long-term relationships with customers, companies can develop loyalty programs that allow customers who check-in via social media regularly at a location to earn discounts or perks. For example, [[American Eagle Outfitters]] remunerates such customers with a tiered 10%, 15%, or 20% discount on their total purchase.<ref>Kaplan, Andreas M. (March–April 2012). "If you love something, let it go mobile: Mobile marketing and mobile social media 4x4". Business Horizons. 55 (2): 129–139. doi:10.1016/j.bushor.2011.10.009.</ref> * Informal employee learning/ organizational development is facilitated by the social media<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ravenscroft|first=A.|last2=Schmidt|first2=A.|last3=Cook|first3=J.|last4=Bradley|first4=C.|date=2012-05-16|title=Designing social media for informal learning and knowledge maturing in the digital workplace|journal=Journal of Computer Assisted Learning|language=en|volume=28|issue=3|pages=235–249|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2729.2012.00485.x|issn=0266-4909}}</ref> Technologies such as blogs, wiki pages, web forums, social networks and other social media act as Technology Enhanced Learning (TEL) tools, and their users perceive change in organizational structure, culture and knowledge management.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cudanov|first=Mladen|last2=Savoiu|first2=Gheorghe|last3=Jasko|first3=Ondrej|date=2012|title=Usage of technology enhanced learning tools and organizational change perception|journal=Computer Science and Information Systems|volume=9|issue=1|pages=285–302|doi=10.2298/csis110106043c|issn=1820-0214}}</ref> *[[e-Commerce]]: Social media sites are increasingly implementing marketing-friendly strategies, creating platforms that are mutually beneficial for users, businesses, and the networks themselves in the popularity and accessibility of e-commerce, or online purchases. The user who posts her or his comments about a company's product or service benefits because they are able to share their views with their online friends and acquaintances. The company benefits because it obtains insight (positive or negative) about how their product or service is viewed by consumers. Mobile social media applications such as [[Amazon.com]] and [[Pinterest]] have started to influence an upward trend in the popularity and accessibility of e-commerce.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/gyro/2012/12/24/10-e-commerce-predictions-for-2013/ |title=gyroVoice: 10 E-Commerce Predictions For 2013 |publisher=Forbes |date=2012-04-18 |accessdate=2013-06-16 |first=Paul |last=Dunay}}</ref>{{qn |date=November 2015}}
[[E-commerce]] businesses may refer to social media as [[consumer-generated media]] (CGM). A common thread running through all definitions of social media is a blending of technology and social interaction for the co-creation of value for the business or organization that is using it. People obtain valuable information, education, news, and other data from electronic and print media. Social media are distinct from industrial and traditional media such as newspapers, magazines, television, and film as they are comparatively inexpensive marketing tools and are highly accessible. They enable anyone, including private individuals, to publish or access information easily. Industrial media generally require significant resources to publish information, and in most cases the articles go through many revisions before being published. This process adds to the cost and the resulting market price. Originally social media was only used by individuals, but now it is used by both businesses and nonprofit organizations and also in government and politics.
One characteristic shared by both social and industrial media is the capability to reach small or large audiences; for example, either a blog post or a television show may reach no people or millions of people.<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://conservancy.umn.edu/handle/11299/172818 |title=Blogging as Social Action: A Genre Analysis of the Weblog |last=R. |first=Miller, Carolyn |last2=Dawn |first2=Shepherd |website=conservancy.umn.edu |language=en |access-date=2016-04-22|year=2004 }}</ref> Some of the properties that help describe the differences between social and industrial media are:
# '''Quality''': In industrial (traditional) publishing—mediated by a publisher—the typical range of quality is substantially narrower (skewing to the high quality side) than in niche, unmediated markets like user-generated social media posts. The main challenge posed by the content in social media sites is the fact that the distribution of quality has high variance: from very high-quality items to low-quality, sometimes even abusive or inappropriate content.<ref name="qualitymedia">{{cite journal |last=Agichtein |first=Eugene |author2=Carlos Castillo. Debora Donato |author3=Aristides Gionis |author4=Gilad Mishne |title=Finding high-quality content in social media |journal=WISDOM – Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Web Search and Data Mining |year=2008 |pages=183–193}}</ref> # '''Reach''': Both industrial and social media technologies provide scale and are capable of reaching a global audience. Industrial media, however, typically use a centralized framework for organization, production, and dissemination, whereas social media are by their very nature more decentralized, less hierarchical, and distinguished by multiple points of production and utility. # '''Frequency''': The number of times users access a type of media per day. Heavy social media users, such as young people, check their social media account numerous times throughout the day. # '''Accessibility''': The means of production for industrial media are typically government or corporate (privately owned); social media tools are generally available to the public at little or no cost, or they are supported by advertising revenue. While social media tools are available to anyone with access to [[Internet]] and a computer or mobile device, due to the [[digital divide]], the poorest segment of the population lacks access to the Internet and computer. Low-income people may have more access to traditional media (TV, radio, etc.), as an inexpensive TV and aerial or radio costs much less than an inexpensive computer or mobile device. Moreover, in many regions, TV or radio owners can tune into free [[Over-the-air programming|over the air]] programming; computer or mobile device owners need Internet access to go to social media sites. # '''Usability''': Industrial media production typically requires specialized skills and training. For example, in the 1970s, to record a pop song, an aspiring singer would have to rent time in an expensive professional [[recording studio]] and hire an [[audio engineer]]. Conversely, most social media activities, such as posting a video of oneself singing a song require only modest reinterpretation of existing skills (assuming a person understands [[Web 2.0]] technologies); in theory, anyone with access to the Internet can operate the means of social media production, and post digital pictures, videos or text online. # '''Immediacy''': The time lag between communications produced by industrial media can be long (days, weeks, or even months, by the time the content has been reviewed by various [[editor]]s and [[fact checker]]s) compared to social media (which can be capable of virtually instantaneous responses). The immediacy of social media can be seen as a strength, in that it enables regular people to instantly communicate their opinions and information. At the same time, the immediacy of social media can also be seen as a weakness, as the lack of fact checking and editorial "gatekeepers" facilitates the circulation of [[hoax]]es and [[fake news]]. # '''Permanence''': Industrial media, once created, cannot be altered (e.g., once a magazine article or paper book is printed and distributed, changes cannot be made to that same article in that print run) whereas social media posts can be altered almost instantaneously, when the user decides to edit their post or due to comments from other readers.
Community media constitute a hybrid of industrial and social media. Though community-owned, some community radio, TV, and newspapers are run by professionals and some by amateurs. They use both social and industrial media frameworks. Social media has also been recognized for the way they have changed how [[public relations]] professionals conduct their jobs.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Wrigh |first=Donald |date=Spring 2008 |title=How blogs and social media are changing public relations and the way it is practiced |url=http://muhammadsaleem.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/02/wrighthinson.pdf |journal=Public Relations Journal |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=22 April 2016 |citeseerx=10.1.1.590.7572}}</ref> They have provided an open arena where people are free to exchange ideas on companies, brands, and products. Doc Searls and David Wagner state that the "...best of the people in PR are not PR types at all. They understand that there aren't censors, they're the company's best conversationalists."<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cluetrain.com/book/markets.html |title=Markets are conversations |publisher=Perseus |author1=R. Levine |author2=C. Locke |author3=D. Searls |author4=D. Weinberger |last-author-amp=yes |location=New York |accessdate=2012-10-22}}</ref> Social media provides an environment where users and PR professionals can converse, and where PR professionals can promote their brand and improve their company's image by listening and responding to what the public is saying about their product.
====Performance benefits====
There are four channels by which social media resources can transform into business performance capabilities:<ref>{{Cite journal |last= Paniagua |first= Jordi |last2= Sapena |first2= Juan |date= 2014 |title= Business performance and social media: Love or hate? |journal= Business Horizons |volume= 57 |issue= 6 |pages= 719–728 |doi= 10.1016/j.bushor.2014.07.005}}</ref> # '''[[Social capital]]''' represents the extent to which social media affects firms' and organizations' relationships with society and the degree to which the organizations' use of social media increases corporate social-performance capabilities. # '''Revealed preferences''' represent the extent to which social media exposes customers' likings (e.g., "likes" and followers) and increase a firm's financial capabilities (e.g., [[stock price]], [[revenue]], [[profit (accounting)|profit]]), or for non-profits, increases their donations, volunteerism rate, etc. # '''Social marketing''' represents the extent to which social-marketing resources (e.g., online conversations, sharing links, online presence, sending text-messages) are used to increase a firm's financial capabilities (e.g., sales, acquisition of new customers) or a non-profit's voluntary sector goals. # '''Social corporate networking''' involves the informal ties and linkages of corporate/organizational staff with other people from their field or industry, clients, customers, and other members of the public, which form through social networks. Social corporate networking can increase operational performance capabilities in many ways, as it can enable sales staff to find new clients; help marketing staff to learn about client/customer needs and demand, and teach management about the public perceptions of their strategy or approach. # '''Influence on consumer decisions''' With the ever-increasing technological development of social media, this has affected consumers' decision to buy the product or service provided by companies.On the other hand, social media has become an important factor in increasing the sales of brands, whether large or small, since the beginning of the Internet revolution. There is much research to prove this, based on the actions taken by the consumer through 2017. There will be many reports at the beginning 2018 confirming the degree to which social media has become effective in marketing companies and the importance of focusing on them.<ref>{{Cite book |chapter-url= https://research.utwente.nl/en/publications/impact-of-online-product-reviews-on-purchasing-decisions |title= Influence on consumer decisions |pages= 271–278 |website= |publisher= |access-date= |doi= 10.5220/0005861002710278 |chapter= Impact of Online Product Reviews on Purchasing Decisions |year= 2016 |last1= Holleschovsky |first1= Nina Isabel |last2= Constantinides |first2= Efthymios |isbn= 978-989-758-186-1 |url= https://research.utwente.nl/en/publications/impact-of-online-product-reviews-on-purchasing-decisions(c5a307e5-8329-4cfc-8b82-f065151fcfbb).html |type= Submitted manuscript }}</ref>
There are four tools or approaches that engage experts, customers, suppliers, and employees in the development of products and services using social media. Companies and other organizations can use these tools and approaches to improve their business capacity and performance.<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://aisel.aisnet.org/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1348&context=ecis2013_cr |title= The Impact Of Social Media On Business Performance |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date= }}</ref> # '''[[Customer relationship management]]''' (CRM) is an approach to managing a company's interaction with current and potential future customers that try to analyze data about customers' history with a company and to improve business relationships with customers, specifically focusing on customer retention and ultimately driving sales growth. One important aspect of the CRM approach is the systems of CRM that compile data from a range of different communication channels, including a company's website, telephone, email, live chat, marketing materials, and social media. Through the CRM approach and the systems used to facilitate CRM, [[business]]es learn more about their target audiences and how to best cater to their needs. However, adopting the CRM approach may also occasionally lead to favoritism within an audience of consumers, resulting in dissatisfaction among customers and defeating the purpose of CRM. # '''[[Innovation]]''' is defined by Michael Szycher as a "new idea, device, or method," or the use of better solutions that accommodate new needs or solve new problems.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oDduDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT260&lpg=PT260&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Szycher's Practical Handbook of Entrepreneurship and Innovation|last=Szycher|first=Michael|date=2018-09-04|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=9781351736367|language=en}}</ref> To accomplish this, more effective products, processes, services, technologies and business models are required by markets, governments and society.<ref name=":0" /> Innovation is something original that occurs via the [[engineering process]] and is able to break into a market and is similar to invention. <ref name=":0" /> In [[industrial economics]], innovations work to meet a growing consumer demand.<ref name=":0" /> # '''[[Training]]''' in social-media techniques, tactics and unwritten rules may not be needed for "[[parseltongue]]s", such as workers who are already comfortable and experienced with using social media. However, for workers who are not familiar with social media, formal or informal training may be needed. [[Brand management]] and [[Brand engagement|engagement]] is done differently on social media platforms than over traditional advertising formats such as TV and radio ads. To give just one example, with traditional ads, customers cannot respond to the ad. However, if an organization makes a major gaffe or [[politically incorrect]] statement on social media, customers and other regular citizens can immediately post comments about the ad. # '''[[Knowledge management]]''' could take place in traditional small businesses (such as [[coffeehouse]]s and [[ice cream parlour]]s) just by using the owner-proprietor's own memory of his key customers, their preferences, and their client-service expectations. However, with the shift to national or even multinational e-commerce businesses which operate online, companies are generating far more data on transactions for a single person or even a team to grasp just in their memory. As such, 2010-era global e-commerce firms typically use a range of digital tools to track, monitor and analyze the huge streams of data their businesses are generating, a process called "[[data mining]]".
====Monitoring, tracking and analysis of consumers==== Companies are increasingly using [[social media monitoring]] tools to monitor, track, and analyze online conversations on the Web about their brand or products or about related topics of interest. This can be useful in [[public relations]] management and [[advertising campaign]] tracking, allowing the companies to measure [[return on investment]] for their social media ad spending, competitor-auditing, and for public engagement. Tools range from free, basic applications to subscription-based, more in-depth tools.
Social media tracking also enables companies to respond quickly to online posts that criticize their product or service. By responding quickly to critical online posts, and helping the user to resolve the concerns, this helps the company to lessen the negative effects that online complaints can have about company product or service sales. In the US, for example, if a customer criticizes a major hotel chain's cleanliness or service standards on a social media website, a company representative will usually quickly be alerted to this critical post, so that the company representative can go online and express concern for the sub-par service and offer the complaining person a [[coupon]] or [[discounts and allowances|discount]] on their next purchase, plus a promise to forward their concerns to the hotel manager so that the problem will not be repeated. This rapid response helps to show that the company cares about its customers.
The "honeycomb framework" defines how social media services focus on some or all of seven functional building blocks.<ref name="Kietzmann">{{cite journal |last=Kietzmann |first=Jan H. |author2=Kristopher Hermkens |title=Social media? Get serious! Understanding the functional building blocks of social media |journal=Business Horizons |year=2011 |volume=54 |issue=3 |pages=241–251 |doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2011.01.005|url=http://summit.sfu.ca/item/18103 |type=Submitted manuscript }}</ref> These building blocks help explain the engagement needs of the social media audience. For instance, [[LinkedIn]] users are thought to care mostly about identity, reputation, and relationships, whereas [[YouTube|YouTube's]] primary features are sharing, conversations, groups, and reputation. Many companies build their own social "containers" that attempt to link the seven functional building blocks around their brands. These are private communities that engage people around a more narrow theme, as in around a particular brand, vocation or hobby, rather than social media containers such as [[Google+]], [[Facebook]], and [[Twitter]]. PR departments face significant challenges in dealing with viral negative sentiment directed at organizations or individuals on social media platforms (dubbed "sentimentitis"), which may be a reaction to an announcement or event.<ref>{{cite web |last=Dhami |first=Nav |title=Outbreaks of sentimentitis – riding the social media tiger |url=http://www.isentia.com/en-nz/blog/outbreaks-of-sentimentitis-riding-the-social-media-tiger |work=Global Connections |accessdate=12 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426142904/http://www.isentia.com/en-nz/blog/outbreaks-of-sentimentitis-riding-the-social-media-tiger |archivedate=26 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> In a 2011 article,<ref name="Kietzmann" /> Jan H. Kietzmann, Kristopher Hermkens, Ian P. McCarthy and Bruno S. Silvestre describe the honeycomb relationship as "present[ing] a framework that defines social media by using ''seven functional building blocks'': identity, conversations, sharing, presence, relationships, reputation, and groups". ===Social authority=== Social media marketing becomes effective through a process called "building social authority". One of the foundation concepts in social media has become that you cannot completely control your message through social media but rather you can simply begin to participate in the "conversation" expecting that you can achieve a significant influence in that conversation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mprcenter.org/blog/2010/08/04/research-survey-launched-social-media-and-influence-of-photos-on-body-image/ |title=Research Survey |publisher=Mprcenter.org |accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref> However, this conversation participation must be cleverly executed because although people are resistant to marketing in general, they are even more resistant to direct or overt marketing through social media platforms. This may seem [[counterintuitive]] but it is the main reason building social authority with credibility is so important. A marketer can generally not expect people to be receptive to a marketing message in and of itself. In the Edelman Trust Barometer report<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edelman.com/trust/2008/ |title=2015 Edelman TrustBarometer |work=Edelman |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725031158/http://www.edelman.com/trust/2008/ |archivedate=2010-07-25 |df= }}</ref> in 2008, the majority (58%) of the respondents reported they most trusted company or product information coming from "people like me" inferred to be information from someone they trusted. In the 2010 Trust Report,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.slideshare.net/slides_eoi/edelman-trust-barometer-2010 |title=Edelman Trust Barometer 2010 |author=EOI Escuela de Organización Industrial |work=slideshare.net|date=2010-02-09 }}</ref> the majority switched to 64% preferring their information from industry experts and academics. According to Inc. Technology's Brent Leary, "This loss of trust, and the accompanying turn towards experts and authorities, seems to be coinciding with the rise of social media and networks."<ref name="Inc. Technology Brent Leary Article">{{cite web|url=http://technology.inc.com/internet/articles/201003/leary.html |title=Inc. Technology Brent Leary Article |publisher=Technology.inc.com |date=22 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110403102611/http://technology.inc.com/internet/articles/201003/leary.html |deadurl=yes |archivedate=3 April 2011 |accessdate=2014-02-09 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edelman.com/trust/2010/ |title=Edelman 2010 Trust Barometer Study |publisher=Edelman.com |accessdate=24 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418222552/http://www.edelman.com/trust/2010/ |archivedate=18 April 2012 |df= }}</ref>
